summary: The research focuses on the revision of the Guidelines for Biosafety in Teaching Laboratories, originally established in 2012 due to a Salmonella Typhimurium outbreak linked to microbiology labs. Over the subsequent years, two more outbreaks prompted the American Society for Microbiology (ASM) to track the implementation and challenges faced by users of the guidelines. In 2018, it was recognized that an update was necessary, leading to the formation of a task force to revise the guidelines. The updated guidelines consolidate the previously separate BSL1 and BSL2 guidelines into a single document to reduce confusion and redundancy. They also incorporate new sections addressing risk assessment and the inclusion of service animals, aiming to resolve issues users encountered with the original guidelines and enhance their effectiveness in teaching laboratories.
